● Higher tenant satisfaction due to comfort and lower utilities
● Environmental benefits align with modern sustainability expectations
Financial Models
Rent-to-Income Optimization:
● Target 25-30% of income for housing costs
● Utility inclusion to provide predictable monthly costs
● Income qualification at 60-120% AMI levels
● Flexible lease terms to accommodate student academic calendars
Utility Cost Considerations:
● SIP construction reduces heating/cooling costs by up to 60%
● Potential utility bill savings: $50-150 monthly per unit
● Energy efficiency allows higher rent while maintaining affordability
● Mississippi's hot climate makes energy efficiency critically important
Development Financing:
● Low-Income Housing Tax Credits (LIHTC)
● Mississippi Home Corporation funding programs
● Private investment attracted by stable rental income
● Potential HUD programs for workforce housing
Policy Recommendations
Zoning and Regulatory:
● Streamlined approval process for workforce housing
● Density bonuses for affordable housing inclusion
● Reduced parking requirements near transit/university
● Fast-track permitting for energy-efficient construction
Financial Incentives:
● Property tax abatements for affordable housing
● Fee reductions for workforce housing developments
● State and local tax credit programs
● Public land dedication for affordable housing
Public-Private Partnerships:
● Joint development with University of Southern Mississippi
● Healthcare system employer-assisted housing programs
